SCENE.STAGEDIR: A tempestuous noise of Thunder and Lightning heard: Enter a Ship-master, and a Boteswaine

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Master.
SPEECH.LINE: Bote-swaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Master: What cheere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mast.
SPEECH.LINE: Good: Speake to th’ Mariners: fall too't, yarely, or we run our ſelues a ground, bestirre, bestirre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: Heigh my hearts, cheerely, cheerely my harts: yare, yare: Take in the toppe-sale: Tend to th’ Masters whistle: Blow till thou burst thy winde, if roome e-nough.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Anthonio, Ferdinando, Gonzalo, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Boteswaine haue care: where's the Ma-ster?
Play the men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray now keepe below.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the Master, Boson?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you not heare him? you marre our labour,
Keepe your Cabines: you do aſſist the ſtorme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good be patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: When the Sea is: hence, what cares these roa-rers for the name of King? to Cabine; ſilence: trouble vs not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: None that I more loue then my ſelfe. You are a Counsellor, if you can command these Elements to ſi-lence, and worke the peace of the present, wee will not hand a rope more, vse your authoritie: If you cannot, giue thankes you haue liu’d ſo long, and make your ſelfe readie in your Cabine for the mischance of the houre, if it ſo hap. Cheerely good hearts: out of our way I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue great comfort from this fellow: methinks he hath no drowning marke vpon him, his complexion is perfect Gallowes: ſtand fast good Fate to his han-ging, make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our owne doth little aduantage: If he be not borne to bee hang’d, our case is miserable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: Downe with the top-Mast: yare, lower, lower, bring her to Try with Maine-course. A plague — A cry within. Enter Sebastian, Anthonio & Gonzalo. vpon this howling: they are lowder then the weather, or our office: yet againe? What do you heere? Shal we giue ore and drowne, haue you a minde to ſinke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sebas.
SPEECH.LINE: A poxe o'your throat, you bawling, blasphe-mous incharitable Dog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: Worke you then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Hang cur, hang, you whoreson insolent Noyse-maker, we are leſſe afraid to be drownde, then thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: I'le warrant him for drowning, though the Ship were no ſtronger then a Nutt-shell, and as leaky as an vnstanched wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: Lay her a hold, a hold, ſet her two courses off to Sea againe, lay her off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mari.
SPEECH.LINE: All lost, to prayers, to prayers, all lost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Botes.
SPEECH.LINE: What must our mouths be cold?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: The King, and Prince, at prayers, let's aſſist them, for our case is as theirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sebas.
SPEECH.LINE: I'am out of patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: We are meerly cheated of our liues by drunkards, This wide-chopt-rascall, would thou mightst lye drow-ning the washing of ten Tides.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee'l be hang’d yet,
Though euery drop of water ſweare against it,
And gape at widst to glut him. A confused noyse within.
Mercy on vs.
We ſplit, we ſplit, Farewell my wife, and children,
Farewell brother: we ſplit, we ſplit, we ſplit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's all ſinke with' King

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb
SPEECH.LINE: Let's take leaue of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Now would I giue a thousand furlongs of Sea, for an Acre of barren ground: Long heath, Browne firrs, any thing; the wills aboue be done, but I would faine dye a dry death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: If by your Art (my deereſt father) you haue
Put the wild waters in this Rore; alay them:
The skye it ſeemes would powre down ſtinking pitch,
But that the Sea, mounting to th’ welkins cheeke,
Dashes the fire out. Oh! I haue ſuffered
With those that I ſaw ſuffer: A braue veſſell
(Who had no doubt ſome noble creature in her)
Dash’d all to peeces: O the cry did knocke
Against my very heart: poore ſoules, they perish’d.
Had I byn any God of power, I would
Haue ſuncke the Sea within the Earth, or ere
It ſhould the good Ship ſo haue ſwallow’d, and
The fraughting Soules within her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Be collected,
No more amazement: Tell your pitteous heart
there's no harme done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O wœ, the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: No harme:
I haue done nothing, but in care of thee
(Of thee my deere one; thee my daughter) who
Art ignorant of what thou art. naught knowing
Of whence I am: nor that I am more better
Then Prospero, Master of a full poore cell,
And thy no greater Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: More to know
Did neuer medle with my thoughts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis time
I ſhould informe thee farther: Lend thy hand
And plucke my Magick garment from me: So,
Lye there my Art: wipe thou thine eyes, haue comfort,
The direfull ſpectacle of the wracke which touch’d
The very vertue of compaſſion in thee:
I haue with ſuch prouision in mine Art
So ſafely ordered, that there is no ſoule
No not ſo much perdition as an hayre
Betid to any creature in the veſſell
Which thou heardst cry, which thou ſaw'st ſinke: Sit downe,
For thou must now know farther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue often
Begun to tell me what I am, but ſtopt
And left me to a booteleſſe Inquisition,
Concluding, ſtay: not yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: The howr's now come
The very minute byds thee ope thine eare,
Obey, and be attentiue. Canst thou remember
A time before we came vnto this Cell?
I doe not thinke thou canst, for then thou was't not
Out three yeeres old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Certainely Sir, I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: By what? by any other house, or person?
Of any thing the Image, tell me, that
Hath kept with thy remembrance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis farre off:
And rather like a dreame, then an aſſurance
That my remembrance warrants: Had I not
Fowre, or fiue women once, that tended me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hadst; and more Miranda: But how is it
That this liues in thy minde? What ſeest thou els
In the dark-backward and Abisme of Time?
Yf thou remembrest ought ere thou cam'st here,
How thou cam'st here thou maist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: But that I doe not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Twelue yere ſince (Miranda) twelue yere ſince,
Thy father was the Duke of Millaine and
A Prince of power:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, are not you my Father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy Mother was a peece of vertue, and
She ſaid thou wast my daughter; and thy father
Was Duke of Millaine, and his onely heire,
And Princeſſe; no worse Iſſued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O the heauens,
What fowle play had we, that we came from thence?
Or bleſſed was't we did?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Both, both my Girle.
By fowle-play (as thou ſaist) were we heau’d thence,
But bleſſedly holpe hither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O my heart bleedes
To thinke oth' teene that I haue turn’d you to,
Which is from my remembrance, please you, farther;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: My brother and thy vncle, call’d Anthonio:
I pray thee marke me, that a brother ſhould
Be ſo perfidious: he, whom next thy ſelfe
Of all the world I lou’d, and to him put
The mannage of my ſtate, as at that time
Through all the ſignories it was the first,
And Prospero, the prime Duke, being ſo reputed
In dignity; and for the liberall Artes,
Without a paralell; those being all my ſtudie,
The Gouernment I cast vpon my brother,
And to my State grew ſtranger, being transported
And rapt in ſecret ſtudies, thy false vncle
(Do'st thou attend me?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, mo’t heedefully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Being once perfected how to graunt ſuites, how to deny them: who t’ aduance, and who To trash for ouer-topping; new created The creatures that were mine, I ſay, or chang’d 'em, Or els new form’d 'em; hauing both the key, Of Officer, and office, ſet all hearts i'th ſtate To what tune pleas’d his eare, that now he was The Iuy which had hid my princely Trunck, And ſuckt my verdure out on't: Thou attend'st not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O good Sir, I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee marke me: I thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closenes, and the bettering of my mind with that, which but by being ſo retir’d Ore-priz’d all popular rate: in my false brother Awak’d an euill nature, and my trust Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood in it's contrarie, as great As my trust was, which had indeede no limit, A confidence ſans bound. He being thus Lorded, Not onely with what my reuenew yeelded, But what my power might els exact. Like one Who hauing into truth, by telling of it, Made ſuch a ſynner of his memorie To credite his owne lie, he did beleeue He was indeed the Duke, out o'th’ Substitution And executing th’ outward face of Roialtie With all prerogatiue: hence his Ambition growing: Do'st thou heare ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Your tale, Sir, would cure deafeneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: To haue no Schreene between this part he plaid,
And him he plaid it for, he needes will be
Absolute Millaine, Me (poore man) my Librarie
Was Dukedome large enough: of temporall roalties
He thinks me now incapable. Confederates
(so drie he was for Sway) with King of Naples
To giue him Annuall tribute, doe him homage
Subiect his Coronet, to his Crowne and bend
The Dukedom yet vnbow’d (alas poore Millaine)
To mo’t ignoble ſtooping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh the heauens:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke his condition, and th’ euent, then tell me
If this might be a brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould ſinne
To thinke but Noblie of my Grand-mother,
Good wombes haue borne bad ſonnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Now the Condition.
This King of Naples being an Enemy
To me inueterate, hearkens my Brothers ſuit,
Which was, That he in lieu o'th’ premises,
Of homage, and I know not how much Tribute,
Should presently extirpate me and mine
Out of the Dukedome, and confer faire Millaine
With all the Honors, on my brother: Whereon
A treacherous Armie leuied, one mid-night
Fated to th’ purpose, did Anthonio open
The gates of Millaine, and ith' dead of darkeneſſe
The ministers for th’ purpose hurried thence
Me, and thy crying ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alack, for pitty:
I not remembring how I cride out then
Will cry it ore againe: it is a hint
That wrings mine eyes too't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare a little further,
And then I'le bring thee to the present busineſſe
Which now's vpon's: without the which, this Story
Were mo’t impertinent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore did they not
That howre destroy vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Well demanded, wench:
My Tale prouokes that question: Deare, they durst not,
So deare the loue my people bore me: nor ſet
A marke ſo bloudy on the busineſſe; but
With colours fairer, painted their foule ends.
In few, they hurried vs a-boord a Barke,
Bore vs ſome Leagues to Sea, where they prepared
A rotten carkaſſe of a Butt, not rigg’d,
Nor tackle, ſayle, nor mast, the very rats
Instinctiuely haue quit it: There they hoyst vs
To cry to th’ Sea, that roard to vs; to ſigh
To th’ windes, whose pitty ſighing backe againe
Did vs but louing wrong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alack, what trouble
Was I then to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: O, a Cherubin
Thou was't that did preserue me; Thou didst ſmile,
Infused with a fortitude from heauen,
When I haue deck’d the ſea with drops full ſalt,
Vnder my burthen groan’d, which rais’d in me
An vndergoing ſtomacke, to beare vp
Against what ſhould ensue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: How came we a ſhore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: By prouidence diuine,
Some food, we had, and ſome fresh water, that
A noble Neopolitan Gonzalo
Out of his Charity, (who being then appointed
Master of this designe) did giue vs, with
Rich garments, linnens, ſtuffs, and neceſſaries
Which ſince haue ſteeded much, ſo of his gentleneſſe
Knowing I lou’d my bookes, he furnishd me
From mine owne Library, with volumes, that
I prize aboue my Dukedome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Would I might
But euer ſee that man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Now I arise,
Sit ſtill, and heare the last of our ſea-sorrow:
Heere in this Iland we arriu’d, and heere
Haue I, thy Schoolemaster, made thee more profit
Then other Princeſſe can, that haue more time
For vainer howres; and Tutors, not ſo carefull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Heuens thank you for't. And now I pray you Sir,
For ſtill ‘tis beating in my minde; your reason
For raysing this Sea-storme?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Know thus far forth,
By accident mo’t ſtrange, bountifull Fortune
(Now my deere Lady) hath mine enemies
Brought to this ſhore: And by my prescience
I finde my Zenith doth depend vpon
A mo’t auspitious ſtarre, whose influence
If now I court not, but omit; my fortunes
Will euer after droope: Heare cease more questions,
Thou art inclinde to ſleepe: ‘tis a good dulneſſe,
And giue it way: I know thou canst not chuse:
Come away, Seruant, come; I am ready now,
Approach my Ariel. Come. Enter Ariel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ari.
SPEECH.LINE: All haile, great Master, graue Sir, haile: I come
To anſwer thy best pleasure; be't to fly,
To ſwim, to diue into the fire: to ride
On the curld clowds: to thy ſtrong bidding, taske
Ariel, and all his Qualitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Hast thou, Spirit,
Performd to point, the Tempest that I bad thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: To euery Article.
I boorded the Kings ſhip: now on the Beake,
Now in the Waste, the Decke, in euery Cabyn,
I flam’d amazement, ſometime I'ld diuide
And burne in many places; on the Top-mast,
The Yards and Bore-spritt, would I flame distinctly,
Then meete, and ioyne. Ioues Lightning, the precursers
O'th dreadfull Thunder-claps more momentarie
And ſight out-running were not; the fire, and cracks
Of ſulphurous roaring, the mo’t mighty Neptune
Seeme to besiege, and make his bold waues tremble,
Yea, his dread Trident ſhake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: My braue Spirit,
Who was ſo firme, ſo constant, that this coyle
Would not infect his reason?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a ſoule
But felt a Feauer of the madde, and plaid
Some tricks of desperation; all but Mariners
Plung’d in the foaming bryne, and quit the veſſell;
Then all a fire with me the Kings ſonne Ferdinand
With haire vp-staring (then like reeds, not haire)
Was the first man that leapt; cride hell is empty,
And all the Diuels are heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Why that’s my ſpirit:
But was not this nye ſhore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Close by, my Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But are they (Ariell) ſafe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a haire perishd:
On their ſustaining garments not a blemish,
But fresher then before: and as thou badst me,
In troops I haue dispersd them 'bout the Isle:
The Kings ſonne haue I landed by himselfe,
Whom I left cooling of the Ayre with ſighes,
In an odde Angle of the Isle, and ſitting
His armes in this ſad knot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Of the Kings ſhip,
The Marriners, ſay how thou hast disposd,
And all the rest o'th’ Fleete?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Safely in harbour
Is the Kings ſhippe, in the deepe Nooke, where once
Thou calldst me vp at midnight to fetch dewe
From the ſtill-vext Bermoothes, there ſhe's hid;
The Marriners all vnder hatches ſtowed,
Who, with a Charme ioynd to their ſuffred labour
I haue left asleep: and for the rest o'th’ Fleet
(Which I dispers’d) they all haue met againe,
And are vpon the Mediterranian Flote
Bound ſadly home for Naples,
Supposing that they ſaw the Kings ſhip wrackt,
And his great person perish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Ariel, thy charge
Exactly is perform’d; but there's more worke:
What is the time o'th’ day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Past the mid ſeason.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: At least two Glaſſes: the time 'twixt ſix & now
Must by vs both be ſpent mo’t preciously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there more toyle? Since y dost giue me pains,
Let me remember thee what thou hast promis’d,
Which is not yet perform’d me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? moodie?
What is't thou canst demand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: My Libertie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Before the time be out? no more:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I prethee,
Remember I haue done thee worthy ſeruice,
Told thee no lyes, made thee no mistakings, ſerv’d
Without or grudge, or grumblings; thou did promise
To bate me a full yeere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou forget
From what a torment I did free thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do'st: & thinkst it much to tread y Ooze
Of the ſalt deepe;
To run vpon the ſharpe winde of the North,
To doe me busineſſe in the veines o'th’ earth
When it is bak’d with frost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe not Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou liest, malignant Thing: hast thou forgot
The fowle Witch Sycorax, who with Age and Enuy
Was growne into a hoope? hast thou forgot her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: No Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou hast: where was ſhe born? ſpeak: tell me:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, in Argier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, was ſhe ſo: I must
Once in a moneth recount what thou hast bin,
Which thou forgetst. This damn’d Witch Sycorax
For mischiefes manifold, and ſorceries terrible
To enter humane hearing, from Argier
Thou know'st was banish’d: for one thing ſhe did
They wold not take her life: Is not this true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: This blew ey’d hag, was hither brought with child,
And here was left by th’ Saylors; thou my ſlaue,
As thou reportst thy ſelfe, was then her ſeruant,
And for thou wast a Spirit too delicate
To act her earthy, and abhord commands,
Refusing her grand hests, ſhe did confine thee
By helpe of her more potent Ministers,
And in her mo’t vnmittigable rage,
Into a clouen Pyne, within which rift
Imprison’d, thou didst painefully remaine
A dozen yeeres: within which ſpace ſhe di’d,
And left thee there: where thou didst vent thy groanes
As fast as Mill-wheeles ſtrike: Then was this Island
(Saue for the Son, that he did littour heere,
A frekelld whelpe, hag-borne) not honour’d with
A humane ſhape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes: Caliban her ſonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Dull thing, I ſay ſo: he, that Caliban
Whom now I keepe in ſeruice, thou best know'st
What torment I did finde thee in; thy grones
Did make wolues howle, and penetrate the breasts
Of euer-angry Beares; it was a torment
To lay vpon the damn’d, which Sycorax
Could not againe vndœ: it was mine Art,
When I arriu’d, and heard thee, that made gape
The Pyne, and let thee out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke thee Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an Oake
And peg-thee in his knotty entrailes, till
Thou hast howl’d away twelue winters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon, Master,
I will be correspondent to command
And doe my ſpryting, gently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe ſo: and after two daies
I will discharge thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: That's my noble Master:
What ſhall I doe? ſay what? what ſhall I doe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe make thy ſelfe like a Nymph o'th’ Sea,
Be ſubiect to no ſight but thine, and mine: inuisible
To euery eye-ball else: goe take this ſhape
And hither come in't: goe: hence
With diligence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Awake, deere hart awake, thou hast ſlept well,
Awake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſtrangenes of your ſtory, put
Heauineſſe in me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Shake it off: Come on,
Wee'll visit Caliban, my ſlaue, who neuer
Yeelds vs kinde answere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis a villaine Sir, I doe not loue to looke on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But as ‘tis
We cannot miſſe him: he do's make our fire,
Fetch in our wood, and ſerues in Offices
That profit vs: What hoa: ſlaue: Caliban:
Thou Earth, thou: ſpeake.
Cal. within.
There's wood enough within.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Come forth I ſay, there's other busines for thee:
Come thou Tortoys, when?
Fine apparision: my queint Ariel,
Hearke in thine eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, it ſhall be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou poysonous ſlaue, got by y diuell himselfe
Vpon thy wicked Dam; come forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: As wicked dewe, as ere my mother brush’d
With Rauens feather from vnwholesome Fen
Drop on you both: A Southwest blow on yee,
And blister you all ore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: For this be ſure, to night thou ſhalt haue cramps,
Side-stitches, that ſhall pen thy breath vp, Vrchins
Shall for that vast of night, that they may worke
All exercise on thee: thou ſhalt be pinch’d
As thicke as hony-combe, each pinch more ſtinging
Then Bees that made 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I must eat my dinner:
This Island's mine by Sycorax my mother,
Which thou tak'st from me: when thou cam'st first
Thou ſtroakst me, & made much of me: wouldst giue me
Water with berries in't: and teach me how
To name the bigger Light, and how the leſſe
That burne by day, and night: and then I lou’d thee
And ſhew’d thee all the qualities o'th’ Isle,
The fresh Springs, Brine-pits; barren place and fertill,
Curs’d be I that did ſo: All the Charmes
Of Sycorax: Toades, Beetles, Batts light on you:
For I am all the Subiects that you haue,
Which first was min owne King: and here you ſty-me
In this hard Rocke, whiles you doe keepe from me
The rest o'th’ Island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou mo’t lying ſlaue,
Whom ſtripes may moue, not kindnes: I haue vs’d thee
(Filth as thou art) with humane care, and lodg’d thee
In mine owne Cell, till thou didst ſeeke to violate
The honor of my childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ho, oh ho, would't had bene done:
Thou didst preuent me, I had peopel’d else
This Isle with Calibans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Abhorred Slaue,
Which any print of goodneſſe wilt not take,
Being capable of all ill: I pittied thee,
Took pains to make thee ſpeak, taught thee each houre
One thing or other: when thou didst not (Sauage)
Know thine owne meaning; but wouldst gabble, like
A thing mo’t brutish, I endow’d thy purposes
With words that made them knowne: But thy vild race
(Tho thou didst learn) had that in't, which good natures
Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou
Deseruedly confin’d into this Rocke, who hadst
Deseru’d more then a prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: You taught me Language, and my profit on't
Is, I know how to curse: the red-plague rid you
For learning me your language.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Hag-seed, hence:
Fetch vs in Fewell, and be quicke thou'rt best
To anſwer other busineſſe: ſhrug'st thou (Malice)
If thou neglectst, or dost vnwillingly
What I command, Ile racke thee with old Crampes,
Fill all thy bones with Aches, make thee rore,
That beasts ſhall tremble at thy dyn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: No, 'pray thee.
I must obey, his Art is of ſuch pow'r,
It would controll my Dams god Setebos,
And make a vaſſaile of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro
SPEECH.LINE: So ſlaue, hence.

LINE.STAGEDIR: Exit Cal.] [Enter Ferdinand & Ariel, inuisible playing & ſinging.

SPEECH.LINE: Come vnto these yellow ſands, and then take hands: Curtsied when you haue, and kist the wilde waues whist: Foote it featly heere, and there, and ſweete Sprights beare the burthen. Burthen dispersedly. Harke, harke, bowgh wawgh: the watch-Dogges barke, bowgh-wawgh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, hark, I heare, the ſtraine of ſtrutting Chanticlere cry cockadidle-dowe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Where ſhold this Musick be? I'th aire, or th’ earth? It ſounds no more: and ſure it waytes vpon Some God o'th’ Iland, ſitting on a banke, Weeping againe the King my Fathers wracke. This Musicke crept by me vpon the waters, Allaying both their fury, and my paſſion With it's ſweet ayre: thence I haue follow’d it (Or it hath drawne me rather) but ‘tis gone. No, it begins againe. Ariell Song. Full fadom fiue thy Father lies, Of his bones are Corrall made: Those are pearles that were his eies, Nothing of him that doth fade, But doth ſuffer a Sea-change Into ſomething rich, & ſtrange: Sea-Nimphs hourly ring his knell. Burthen: ding dong. Harke now I heare them, ding-dong bell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: The Ditty do's remember my drown’d father,
This is no mortall busines, nor no ſound
That the earth owes: I heare it now aboue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: The fringed Curtaines of thine eye aduance,
And ſay what thou ſee'st yond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: What is't a Spirit?
Lord, how it lookes about: Beleeue me ſir,
It carries a braue forme. But ‘tis a ſpirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No wench, it eats, and ſleeps, & hath ſuch ſenses
As we haue: ſuch. This Gallant which thou ſeest
Was in the wracke: and but hee's ſomething ſtain’d
With greefe (that’s beauties canker) y might'st call him
A goodly person: he hath lost his fellowes,
And ſtrayes about to finde 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: I might call him
A thing diuine, for nothing naturall
I euer ſaw ſo Noble.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: It goes on I ſee
As my ſoule prompts it: Spirit, fine ſpirit, Ile free thee
Within two dayes for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſure the Goddeſſe
On whom these ayres attend: Vouchsafe my pray'r
May know if you remaine vpon this Island,
And that you will ſome good instruction giue
How I may beare me heere: my prime request
(Which I do last pronounce) is (O you wonder)
If you be Mayd, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: No wonder Sir,
But certainly a Mayd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: My Language? Heauens:
I am the best of them that ſpeake this ſpeech,
Were I but where ‘tis ſpoken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: How? the best?
What wer't thou if the King of Naples heard thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſingle thing, as I am now, that wonders
To heare thee ſpeake of Naples: he do's heare me,
And that he do's, I weepe: my ſelfe am Naples,
Who, with mine eyes (neuer ſince at ebbe) beheld
The King my Father wrack't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, for mercy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes faith, & all his Lords, the Duke of Millaine
And his braue ſonne, being twaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke of Millaine
And his more brauer daughter, could controll thee
If now 'twere fit to do't: At the first ſight
They haue chang’d eyes: Delicate Ariel,
Ile ſet thee free for this. A word good Sir,
I feare you haue done your ſelfe ſome wrong: A word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſpeakes my father ſo vngently? This
Is the third man that ere I ſaw: the first
That ere I ſigh’d for: pitty moue my father
To be enclin’d my way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: O, if a Virgin,
And your affection not gone forth, Ile make you
The Queene of Naples.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft ſir, one word more.
They are both in eythers pow'rs: But this ſwift busines
I must vneasie make, least too light winning
Make the prize light. One word more: I charge thee
That thou attend me: Thou do'st heere vsurpe
The name thou ow'st not, and hast put thy ſelfe
Vpon this Island, as a ſpy, to win it
From me, the Lord on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No, as I am a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Ther's nothing ill, can dwell in ſuch a Temple,
If the ill-spirit haue ſo fayre a house,
Good things will ſtriue to dwell with't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake not you for him: hee's a Traitor: come,
Ile manacle thy necke and feete together:
Sea water ſhalt thou drinke: thy food ſhall be
The fresh-brooke Muſſels, wither’d roots, and huskes
Wherein the Acorne cradled. Follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No,
I will resist ſuch entertainment, till
Mine enemy ha's more pow'r.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He drawes, and is charmed from mouing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: O deere Father,
Make not too rash a triall of him, for
Hee's gentle, and not fearfull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: What I ſay,
My foote my Tutor? Put thy ſword vp Traitor,
Who mak'st a ſhew, but dar'st not ſtrike: thy conscience
Is ſo poſſest with guilt: Come, from thy ward,
For I can heere disarme thee with this ſticke,
And make thy weapon drop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Beseech you Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Hence: hang not on my garments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir haue pity,
Ile be his ſurety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Silence: One word more
Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee: What,
An aduocate for an Impostor? Hush:
Thou think'st there is no more ſuch ſhapes as he,
(Hauing ſeene but him and Caliban:) Foolish wench,
To th’ mo’t of men, this is a Caliban,
And they to him are Angels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: My affections
Are then mo’t humble: I haue no ambition
To ſee a goodlier man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on, obey:
Thy Nerues are in their infancy againe.
And haue no vigour in them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: So they are:
My ſpirits, as in a dreame, are all bound vp:
My Fathers loſſe, the weakneſſe which I feele,
The wracke of all my friends, nor this mans threats,
To whom I am ſubdude, are but light to me,
Might I but through my prison once a day
Behold this Mayd: all corners else o'th’ Earth
Let liberty make vse of: ſpace enough
Haue I in ſuch a prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: It workes: Come on.
Thou hast done well, fine Ariell: follow me,
Harke what thou else ſhalt do mee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mira.
SPEECH.LINE: Be of comfort,
My Fathers of a better nature (Sir)
Then he appeares by ſpeech: this is vnwonted
Which now came from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt be as free
As mountaine windes; but then exactly do
All points of my command.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: To th’ ſyllable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pros
SPEECH.LINE: Come follow: ſpeake not for him.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Anthonio, Gonzalo, Adrian, Francisco, and others

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gonz.
SPEECH.LINE: Beseech you Sir, be merry; you haue cause,
(So haue we all) of ioy; for our escape
Is much beyond our loſſe; our hint of wœ
Is common, euery day, ſome Saylors wife,
The Masters of ſome Merchant, and the Merchant
Haue iust our Theame of wœ: But for the miracle,
(I meane our preseruation) few in millions
Can ſpeake like vs: then wisely (good Sir) weigh
Our ſorrow, with our comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alons.
SPEECH.LINE: Prethee peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He receiues comfort like cold porredge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The Visitor will not giue him ore ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke, hee's winding vp the watch of his wit,
By and by it will ſtrike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: One: Tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: When euery greefe is entertaind,
That's offer’d comes to th’ entertainer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: A dollor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Dolour comes to him indeed, you haue ſpoken truer then you purpos’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue taken it wiselier then I meant you ſhould.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, what a ſpend-thrift is he of his tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: I pre-thee ſpare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I haue done: But yet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He will be talking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Which, of he, or Adrian, for a good wager,
First begins to crow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: The old Cocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The Cockrell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Done: The wager?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: A Laughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: A match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Though this Island ſeeme to be desert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: So: you'r paid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Vninhabitable, and almost inacceſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: He could not miſſe't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: It must needs be of ſubtle, tender, and delicate temperance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Temperance was a delicate wench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and a ſubtle, as he mo’t learnedly deliuer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adr.
SPEECH.LINE: The ayre breathes vpon vs here mo’t ſweetly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: As if it had Lungs, and rotten ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Or, as 'twere perfum’d by a Fen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is euery thing aduantageous to life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: True, ſaue meanes to liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Of that there's none, or little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: How lush and lusty the graſſe lookes?
How greene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The ground indeed is tawny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: With an eye of greene in't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: He miſſes not much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: No: he doth but mistake the truth totally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: But the rariety of it is, which is indeed almost beyond credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: As many voucht rarieties are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: That our Garments being (as they were) drencht in the Sea, hold notwithstanding their freshneſſe and gloſſes, being rather new dy’de then ſtain’d with ſalte water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: If but one of his pockets could ſpeake, would it not ſay he lyes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or very falsely pocket vp his report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Affricke, at the marriage of the kings faire daughter Claribel to the king of Tunis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas a ſweet marriage, and we prosper well in our returne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Tunis was neuer grac’d before with ſuch a Pa-ragon to their Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſince widdow Dido's time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Widow? A pox o'that: how came that Wid-dow in? Widdow Dido!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What if he had ſaid Widdower Aeneas too?
Good Lord, how you take it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Widdow Dido ſaid you? You make me ſtudy of that: She was of Carthage, not of Tunis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: This Tunis Sir was Carthage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adri.
SPEECH.LINE: Carthage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I aſſure you Carthage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: His word is more then the miraculous Harpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath rais’d the wall, and houses too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What impoſſible matter wil he make easy next?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke hee will carry this Island home in his pocket, and giue it his ſonne for an Apple.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſowing the kernels of it in the Sea, bring forth more Islands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Why in good time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, we were talking, that our garments ſeeme now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And the rarest that ere came there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Bate (I beseech you) widdow Dido.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O Widdow Dido? I, Widdow Dido.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not Sir my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I meane in a ſort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſort was well fish’d for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: When I wore it at your daughters marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: You cram these words into mine eares, against the ſtomacke of my ſense: would I had neuer Married my daughter there: For comming thence My ſonne is lost, and (in my rate) ſhe too, Who is ſo farre from Italy remoued, I ne're againe ſhall ſee her: O thou mine heire Of Naples and of Millaine, what ſtrange fish Hath made his meale on thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir he may liue,
I ſaw him beate the ſurges vnder him,
And ride vpon their backes; he trod the water
Whose enmity he flung aside: and brested
The ſurge mo’t ſwolne that met him: his bold head
'Boue the contentious waues he kept, and oared
Himselfe with his good armes in lusty ſtroke
To th’ ſhore; that ore his waue-worne basis bowed
As ſtooping to releeue him: I not doubt
He came aliue to Land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, hee's gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir you may thank your ſelfe for this great loſſe,
That would not bleſſe our Europe with your daughter,
But rather loose her to an Affrican,
Where ſhe at least, is banish’d from your eye,
Who hath cause to wet the greefe on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre-thee peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: You were kneel’d too, & importun’d otherwise
By all of vs: and the faire ſoule her ſelfe
Waigh’d betweene loathneſſe, and obedience, at
Which end o'th’ beame ſhould bow: we haue lost your ſon,
I feare for euer: Millaine and Naples haue
Mo widdowes in them of this busineſſe making,
Then we bring men to comfort them:
The faults your owne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: So is the deer'st oth' loſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord Sebastian,
The truth you ſpeake doth lacke ſome gentleneſſe,
And time to ſpeake it in: you rub the ſore,
When you ſhould bring the plaister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And mo’t Chirurgeonly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: It is foule weather in vs all, good Sir,
When you are cloudy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Fowle weather?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Very foule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Had I plantation of this Isle my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee’d ſow't with Nettle-seed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Or dockes, or Mallowes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: And were the King on't, what would I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Scape being drunke, for want of Wine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I'th’ Commonwealth I would (by contraries)
Execute all things: For no kinde of Trafficke
Would I admit: No name of Magistrate:
Letters ſhould not be knowne: Riches, pouerty,
And vse of ſeruice, none: Contract, Succeſſion,
Borne, bound of Land, Tilth, Vineyard none:
No vse of Mettall, Corne, or Wine, or Oyle:
No occupation, all men idle, all:
And Women too, but innocent and pure:
No Soueraignty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet he would be King on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: The latter end of his Common-wealth forgets the beginning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: All things in common Nature ſhould produce
Without ſweat or endeuour: Treason, fellony,
Sword, Pike, Knife, Gun, or neede of any Engine
Would I not haue: but Nature ſhould bring forth
Of it owne kinde, all foyzon, all abundance
To feed my innocent people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: No marrying 'mong his ſubiects?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: None (man) all idle; Whores and knaues,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I would with ſuch perfection gouerne Sir:
T' Excell the Golden Age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Saue his Maiesty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Long liue Gonzalo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: And do you marke me, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Pre-thee no more: thou dost talke nothing to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I do well beleeue your Highneſſe, and did it to minister occasion to these Gentlemen, who are of ſuch ſensible and nimble Lungs, that they alwayes vse to laugh at nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Twas you we laugh’d at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you: ſo you may continue, and laugh at nothing ſtill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: What a blow was there giuen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: And it had not falne flat-long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: You are Gentlemen of braue mettal: you would lift the Moone out of her ſpheare, if ſhe would continue in it fiue weekes without changing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: We would ſo, and then go a Bat-fowling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay good my Lord, be not angry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: No I warrant you, I will not aduenture my discretion ſo weakly: Will you laugh me asleepe, for I am very heauy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſleepe, and heare vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: What, all ſo ſoone asleepe? I wish mine eyes
Would (with themselues) ſhut vp my thoughts,
I finde they are inclin’d to do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you Sir,
Do not omit the heauy offer of it:
It ſildome visits ſorrow, when it doth, it is a Comforter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: We two my Lord, will guard your person,
While you take your rest, and watch your ſafety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alon.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke you: Wondrous heauy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What a ſtrange drowsines poſſeſſes them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the quality o'th’ Clymate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Why
Doth it not then our eye-lids ſinke? I finde
Not my ſelfe dispos’d to ſleep.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I, my ſpirits are nimble:
They fell together all, as by consent
They dropt, as by a Thunder-stroke: what might
Worthy Sebastian? O, what might? no more:
And yet, me thinkes I ſee it in thy face,
What thou ſhould'st be: th’ occasion ſpeaks thee, and
My ſtrong imagination ſee's a Crowne
Dropping vpon thy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What? art thou waking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you not heare me ſpeake?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I do, and ſurely
It is a ſleepy Language; and thou ſpeak'st
Out of thy ſleepe: What is it thou didst ſay?
This is a ſtrange repose, to be asleepe
With eyes wide open: ſtanding, ſpeaking, mouing:
And yet ſo fast asleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Sebastian,
Thou let'st thy fortune ſleepe: die rather: wink'st
Whiles thou art waking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do'st ſnore distinctly,
There's meaning in thy ſnores.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I am more ſerious then my custome: you
Must be ſo too, if heed me: which to do,
Trebbles thee o’re.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I am ſtanding water.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile teach you how to flow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Do ſo: to ebbe
Hereditary Sloth instructs me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O!
If you but knew how you the purpose cherish
Whiles thus you mocke it: how in ſtripping it
You more inuest it: ebbing men, indeed
(Mo’t often) do ſo neere the bottome run
By their owne feare, or ſloth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Pre-thee ſay on,
The ſetting of thine eye, and cheeke proclaime
A matter from thee; and a birth, indeed,
Which throwes thee much to yeeld.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus Sir:
Although this Lord of weake remembrance; this
Who ſhall be of as little memory
When he is earth’d, hath here almost perswaded
(For hee's a Spirit of perswasion, onely
Profeſſes to perswade) the King his ſonne's aliue,
‘Tis as impoſſible that hee's vndrown’d,
As he that ſleepes heere, ſwims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue no hope
That hee's vndrown’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O, out of that no hope,
What great hope haue you? No hope that way, Is
Another way ſo high a hope, that euen
Ambition cannot pierce a winke beyond
But doubt discouery there. Will you grant with me
That Ferdinand is drown’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: He's gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Then tell me, who's the next heire of Naples?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Claribell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: She that is Queene of Tunis: ſhe that dwels
Ten leagues beyond mans life: ſhe that from Naples
Can haue no note, vnleſſe the Sun were post:
The Man i'th Moone's too ſlow, till new-borne chinnes
Be rough, and Razor-able: She that from whom
We all were ſea-swallow’d, though ſome cast againe,
(And by that destiny) to performe an act
Whereof, what’s past is Prologue; what to come
In yours, and my discharge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſtuffe is this? How ſay you?
‘Tis true my brothers daughter's Queene of Tunis,
So is ſhe heyre of Naples, 'twixt which Regions
There is ſome ſpace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſpace, whose eu'ry cubit
Seemes to cry out, how ſhall that Claribell
Measure vs backe to Naples? keepe in Tunis,
And let Sebastian wake. Say, this were death
That now hath ſeiz’d them, why they were no worse
Then now they are: There be that can rule Naples
As well as he that ſleepes: Lords, that can prate
As amply, and vnneceſſarily
As this Gonzallo: I my ſelfe could make
A Chough of as deepe chat: O, that you bore
The minde that I do; what a ſleepe were this
For your aduancement? Do you vnderstand me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: And how do's your content
Tender your owne good fortune?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I remember
You did ſupplant your Brother Prospero.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: True:
And looke how well my Garments ſit vpon me,
Much feater then before: My Brothers ſeruants
Were then my fellowes, now they are my men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: But for your conscience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir: where lies that? If 'twere a kybe
'Twould put me to my ſlipper: But I feele not
This Deity in my bosome: 'Twentie consciences
That ſtand 'twixt me, and Millaine, candied be they,
And melt ere they mollest: Heere lies your Brother,
No better then the earth he lies vpon,
If he were that which now hee's like (that’s dead)
Whom I with this obedient ſteele (three inches of it)
Can lay to bed for euer: whiles you doing thus,
To the perpetuall winke for aye might put
This ancient morsell: this Sir Prudence, who
Should not vpbraid our course: for all the rest
They'l take ſuggestion, as a Cat laps milke,
They'l tell the clocke, to any busineſſe that
We ſay befits the houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy case, deere Friend
Shall be my president: As thou got'st Millaine,
I'le come by Naples: Draw thy ſword, one ſtroke
Shall free thee from the tribute which thou paiest,
And I the King ſhall loue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Draw together:
And when I reare my hand, do you the like
To fall it on Gonzalo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: O, but one word.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Ariell with Musicke and Song.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariel.
SPEECH.LINE: My Master through his Art foresees the danger
That you (his friend) are in, and ſends me forth
(For else his proiect dies) to keepe them liuing.
While you here do ſnoaring lie,
Open-ey’d Conspiracie
His time doth take:
If of Life you keepe a care,
Shake off ſlumber and beware.
Awake, awake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Then let vs both be ſodaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, good Angels preserue the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now hoa; awake? why are you drawn?
Wherefore this ghastly looking?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: Whiles we ſtood here ſecuring your repose,
(Euen now) we heard a hollow burst of bellowing
Like Buls, or rather Lyons, did't not wake you?
It ſtrooke mine eare mo’t terribly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: O, 'twas a din to fright a Monsters eare;
To make an earthquake: ſure it was the roare
Of a whole heard of Lyons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Heard you this Gonzalo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon mine honour, Sir, I heard a humming,
(And that a ſtrange one too) which did awake me:
I ſhak’d you Sir, and cride: as mine eyes opend,
I ſaw their weapons drawne: there was a noyse,
That's verily: ‘tis best we ſtand vpon our guard;
Or that we quit this place: let's draw our weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Lead off this ground & let's make further ſearch
For my poore ſonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens keepe him from these Beasts:
For he is ſure i'th Island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Lead away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Prospero my Lord, ſhall know what I haue done. So (King) goe ſafely on to ſeeke thy Son.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Caliban, with a burthen of Wood (a noyse of thunder heard.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: All the infections that the Sunne ſuckes vp
From Bogs, Fens, Flats, on Prosper fall, and make him
By ynch-meale a disease: his Spirits heare me,
And yet I needes must curse. But they'll nor pinch,
Fright me with Vrchyn-shewes, pitch me i'th mire,
Nor lead me like a fire-brand, in the darke
Out of my way, vnleſſe he bid 'em; but
For euery trifle, are they ſet vpon me,
Sometime like Apes, that moe and chatter at me,
And after bite me: then like Hedg-hogs, which
Lye tumbling in my bare-foote way, and mount
Their pricks at my foot-fall: ſometime am I
All wound with Adders, who with clouen tongues
Doe hiſſe me into madneſſe: Lo, now Lo, Enter Trinculo.
Here comes a Spirit of his, and to torment me
For bringing wood in ſlowly: I'le fall flat,
Perchance he will not minde me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Here's neither bush, nor ſhrub to beare off any weather at all: and another Storme brewing, I heare it ſing ith' winde: yond ſame blacke cloud, yond huge one, lookes like a foule bumbard that would ſhed his licquor: if it ſhould thunder, as it did before, I know not where to hide my head: yond ſame cloud cannot choose but fall by paile-fuls. What haue we here, a man, or a fish? dead or aliue? a fish, hee ſmels like a fish: a very ancient and fish-like ſmell: a kinde of, not of the newest poore-Iohn: a ſtrange fish: were I in England now (as once I was) and had but this fish painted; not a holiday-foole there but would giue a peece of ſiluer: there, would this Monster, make a man: any ſtrange beast there, makes a man: when they will not giue a doit to relieue a lame Begger, they will lay out ten to ſee a dead Indian: Leg’d like a man; and his Finnes like Armes: warme o'my troth: I doe now let loose my o-pinion; hold it no longer; this is no fish, but an Islan-der, that hath lately ſuffered by a Thunderbolt: Alas, the ſtorme is come againe: my best way is to creepe vn-der his Gaberdine: there is no other ſhelter herea-bout: Misery acquaints a man with ſtrange bedfel-lowes: I will here ſhrowd till the dregges of the ſtorme be past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall no more to ſea, to ſea, here ſhall I dye ashore.
This is a very ſcuruy tune to ſing at a mans
Funerall: well, here's my comfort.
The Master, the Swabber, the Boate-swaine & I;
The Gunner, and his Mate
Lou’d Mall, Meg, and Marrian, and Margerie,
But none of vs car’d for Kate.
For ſhe had a tongue with a tang,
Would cry to a Sailor goe hang:
She lou’d not the ſauour of Tar nor of Pitch,
Yet a Tailor might ſcratch her where ere ſhe did itch.
Then to Sea Boyes, and let her goe hang.
This is a ſcuruy tune too:
But here's my comfort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not torment me: oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: What's the matter? Haue we diuels here? Doe you put trickes vpon's with Saluages, and Men of Inde? ha? I haue not ſcap’d drowning, to be afeard now of your foure legges: for it hath bin ſaid; as pro-per a man as euer went on foure legs, cannot make him giue ground: and it ſhall be ſaid ſo againe, while Ste-phano breathes at' nostrils.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Spirit torments me: oh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: This is ſome Monster of the Isle, with foure legs; who hath got (as I take it) an Ague: where the diuell ſhould he learne our language? I will giue him ſome re-liefe if it be but for that: if I can recouer him, and keepe him tame, and get to Naples with him, he's a Pre-sent for any Emperour that euer trod on Neates-lea-ther. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not torment me 'prethee: I'le bring my wood home faster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: He's in his fit now; and doe's not talke after the wisest; hee ſhall taste of my Bottle: if hee haue neuer drunke wine afore, it will goe neere to remoue his Fit: if I can recouer him, and keepe him tame, I will not take too much for him; hee ſhall pay for him that hath him, and that ſoundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou do'st me yet but little hurt; thou wilt a-non, I know it by thy trembling: Now Prosper workes vpon thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on your wayes: open your mouth: here is that which will giue language to you Cat; open your mouth; this will ſhake your ſhaking, I can tell you, and that ſoundly: you cannot tell who's your friend; open your chaps againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhould know that voyce: It ſhould be, But hee is dround; and these are diuels; O de-fend me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Foure legges and two voyces; a mo’t delicate Monster: his forward voyce now is to ſpeake well of his friend; his backward voice, is to vtter foule ſpeeches, and to detract: if all the wine in my bottle will recouer him, I will helpe his Ague: Come: Amen, I will poure ſome in thy other mouth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Stephano.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy, mercy: This is a diuell, and no Monster: I will leaue him, I haue no long Spoone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Stephano: if thou beest Stephano, touch me, and ſpeake to me: for I am Trinculo; be not afeard, thy good friend Trinculo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou bee'st Trinculo: come forth: I'le pull thee by the leſſer legges: if any be Trinculo's legges, these are they: Thou art very Trinculo indeede: how cam'st thou to be the ſiege of this Moone-calfe? Can he vent Trinculo's?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: I tooke him to be kil’d with a thunder-strok; but art thou not dround Stephano: I hope now thou art not dround: Is the Storme ouer-blowne? I hid mee vnder the dead Moone-Calfes Gaberdine, for feare of the Storme: And art thou liuing Stephano? O Stephano, two Neapolitanes ſcap’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Prethee doe not turne me about, my ſtomacke is not constant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: These be fine things, and if they be not ſprights: that’s a braue God, and beares Celestiall liquor: I will kneele to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: How did'st thou ſcape? How cam'st thou hither? Sweare by this Bottle how thou cam'st hither: I escap’d vpon a But of Sacke, which the Saylors heaued o’re-boord, by this Bottle which I made of the barke of a Tree, with mine owne hands, ſince I was cast a'-shore. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I'le ſweare vpon that Bottle, to be thy true ſub-iect, for the liquor is not earthly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: St.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere: ſweare then how thou escap’dst.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: Swom ashore (man) like a Ducke: I can ſwim like a Ducke i'le be ſworne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Here, kiſſe the Booke. Though thou canst ſwim like a Ducke, thou art made like a Goose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: O Stephano, ha'st any more of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: The whole But (man) my Cellar is in a rocke by th’ ſea-side, where my Wine is hid: How now Moone-Calfe, how do's thine Ague?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha'st thou not dropt from heauen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Out o'th Moone I doe aſſure thee. I was the
Man ith' Moone, when time was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſeene thee in her: and I doe adore thee:
My Mistris ſhew’d me thee, and thy Dog, and thy Bush.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, ſweare to that: kiſſe the Booke: I will furnish it anon with new Contents: Sweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: By this good light, this is a very ſhallow Mon-ster:
I afeard of him? a very weake Monster:
The Man ith' Moone?
A mo’t poore creadulous Monster:
Well drawne Monster, in good ſooth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſhew thee euery fertill ynch o'th Island: and
I will kiſſe thy foote: I prethee be my god.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: By this light, a mo’t perfidious, and drunken
Monster, when's god's a ſleepe he'll rob his Bottle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile kiſſe thy foot, Ile ſweare my ſelfe thy Subiect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on then: downe and ſweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall laugh my ſelfe to death at this puppi-hea-ded Monster: a mo’t ſcuruie Monster: I could finde in my heart to beate him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, kiſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: But that the poore Monster's in drinke:
An abhominable Monster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I'le ſhew thee the best Springs: I'le plucke thee Berries: I'le fish for thee; and get thee wood enough. A plague vpon the Tyrant that I ſerue; I'le beare him no more Stickes, but follow thee, thou wondrous man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: A mo’t rediculous Monster, to make a wonder of a poore drunkard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I 'prethee let me bring thee where Crabs grow; and I with my long nayles will digge thee pig-nuts; ſhow thee a Iayes nest, and instruct thee how to ſnare the nimble Marmazet: I'le bring thee to clustring Philbirts, and ſometimes I'le get thee young Scamels from the Rocke: Wilt thou goe with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I pre'thee now lead the way without any more talking. Trinculo, the King, and all our company else being dround, wee will inherit here: Here; beare my Bottle: Fellow Trinculo; we'll fill him by and by a-gaine. _ Caliban Sings drunkenly. Farewell Master; farewell, farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tri.
SPEECH.LINE: A howling Monster: a drunken Monster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: No more dams I'le make for fish, Nor fetch in firing, at requiring, Nor ſcrape trenchering, nor wash dish, Ban' ban' Cacalyban Has a new Master, get a new Man. Freedome, high-day, high-day freedome, freedome high-day, freedome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste
SPEECH.LINE: O braue Monster; lead the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: There be ſome Sports are painfull; & their labor
Delight in them ſet off: Some kindes of baseneſſe
Are nobly vndergon; and mo’t poore matters
Point to rich ends: this my meane Taske
Would be as heauy to me, as odious, but
The Mistris which I ſerue, quickens what’s dead,
And makes my labours, pleasures: O She is
Ten times more gentle, then her Father's crabbed;
And he's compos’d of harshneſſe. I must remoue
Some thousands of these Logs, and pile them vp,
Vpon a ſore iniunction; my ſweet Mistris
Weepes when ſhe ſees me worke, & ſaies, ſuch basenes
Had neuer like Executor: I forget:
But these ſweet thoughts, doe euen refresh my labours,
Mo’t busie lest, when I doe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, now pray you
Worke not ſo hard: I would the lightning had
Burnt vp those Logs that you are enioynd to pile:
Pray ſet it downe, and rest you: when this burnes
'Twill weepe for hauing wearied you: my Father
Is hard at ſtudy; pray now rest your ſelfe,
Hee's ſafe for these three houres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: O mo’t deere Mistris
The Sun will ſet before I ſhall discharge
What I must ſtriue to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: If you'l ſit downe
Ile beare your Logges the while: pray giue me that,
Ile carry it to the pile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No precious Creature,
I had rather cracke my ſinewes, breake my backe,
Then you ſhould ſuch dishonor vndergœ,
While I ſit lazy by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: It would become me
As well as it do's you; and I ſhould do it
With much more ease: for my good will is to it,
And yours it is against.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Poore worme thou art infected,
This visitation ſhewes it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: You looke wearily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: No, noble Mistris, ‘tis fresh morning with me
When you are by at night: I do beseech you
Cheefely, that I might ſet it in my prayers,
What is your name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Miranda, O my Father,
I haue broke your hest to ſay ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Admir’d Miranda,
Indeede the top of Admiration, worth
What's deerest to the world: full many a Lady
I haue ey’d with best regard, and many a time
Th’ harmony of their tongues, hath into bondage
Brought my too diligent eare: for ſeuerall vertues
Haue I lik’d ſeuerall women, neuer any
With ſo full ſoule, but ſome defect in her
Did quarrell with the noblest grace ſhe ow’d,
And put it to the foile. But you, O you,
So perfect, and ſo peerleſſe, are created
Of euerie Creatures best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know
One of my ſexe; no womans face remember,
Saue from my glaſſe, mine owne: Nor haue I ſeene
More that I may call men, then you good friend,
And my deere Father: how features are abroad
I am ſkilleſſe of; but by my modestie
(The iewell in my dower) I would not wish
Any Companion in the world but you:
Nor can imagination forme a ſhape
Besides your ſelfe, to like of: but I prattle
Something too wildely, and my Fathers precepts
I therein do forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: I am, in my condition
A Prince (Miranda) I do thinke a King
(I would not ſo) and would no more endure
This wodden ſlauerie, then to ſuffer
The flesh-flie blow my mouth: heare my ſoule ſpeake.
The verie instant that I ſaw you, did
My heart flie to your ſeruice, there resides
To make me ſlaue to it, and for your ſake
Am I this patient Logge-man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you loue me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: O heauen; O earth, beare witnes to this ſound,
And crowne what I profeſſe with kinde euent
If I ſpeake true: if hollowly, inuert
What best is boaded me, to mischiefe: I,
Beyond all limit of what else i'th world
Do loue, prize, honor you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a foole
To weepe at what I am glad of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire encounter
Of two mo’t rare affections: heauens raine grace
On that which breeds betweene 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore weepe you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: At mine vnworthineſſe, that dare not offer
What I desire to giue; and much leſſe take
What I ſhall die to want: But this is trifling,
And all the more it ſeekes to hide it ſelfe,
The bigger bulke it ſhewes. Hence bashfull cunning,
And prompt me plaine and holy innocence.
I am your wife, if you will marrie me;
If not, Ile die your maid: to be your fellow
You may denie me, but Ile be your ſeruant
Whether you will or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: My Mistris (deerest)
And I thus humble euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: My husband then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer.
SPEECH.LINE: I, with a heart as willing
As bondage ere of freedome: heere's my hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mir.
SPEECH.LINE: And mine, with my heart in't; and now farewel
Till halfe an houre hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fer
SPEECH.LINE: A thousand, thousand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: So glad of this as they I cannot be,
Who are ſurpriz’d with all; but my reioycing
At nothing can be more: Ile to my booke,
For yet ere ſupper time, must I performe
Much busineſſe appertaining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell not me, when the But is out we will drinke water, not a drop before; therefore beare vp, & boord em' Seruant Monster, drinke to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Seruant Monster? the folly of this Iland, they ſay there's but fiue vpon this Isle; we are three of them, if th’ other two be brain’d like vs, the State totters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Drinke ſeruant Monster when I bid thee, thy eies are almost ſet in thy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where ſhould they bee ſet else? hee were a braue Monster indeede if they were ſet in his taile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: My man-Monster hath drown’d his tongue in ſacke: for my part the Sea cannot drowne mee, I ſwam ere I could recouer the ſhore, fiue and thirtie Leagues off and on, by this light thou ſhalt bee my Lieutenant Monster, or my Standard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Lieutenant if you list, hee's no ſtandard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Weel not run Monsieur Monster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor go neither: but you'l lie like dogs, and yet ſay nothing neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Moone-calfe, ſpeak once in thy life, if thou beest a good Moone-calfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: How does thy honour? Let me licke thy ſhoœ:
Ile not ſerue him, he is not valiant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou liest mo’t ignorant Monster, I am in case to iustle a Constable: why, thou debosh’d Fish thou, was there euer man a Coward, that hath drunk ſo much Sacke as I to day? wilt thou tell a monstrous lie, being but halfe a Fish, and halfe a Monster?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Lœ, how he mockes me, wilt thou let him my
Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord, quoth he? that a Monster ſhould be ſuch a Naturall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Lœ, lœ againe: bite him to death I prethee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Trinculo, keepe a good tongue in your head: If you proue a mutineere, the next Tree: the poore Mon-ster's my ſubiect, and he ſhall not ſuffer indignity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke my noble Lord. Wilt thou be pleas’d to hearken once againe to the ſuite I made to thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry will I: kneele, and repeate it,
I will ſtand, and ſo ſhall Trinculo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: As I told thee before, I am ſubiect to a Tirant,
A Sorcerer, that by his cunning hath cheated me
Of the Island.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lyest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou lyest, thou iesting Monkey thou:
I would my valiant Master would destroy thee.
I do not lye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in's tale,
By this hand, I will ſupplant ſome of your teeth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, I ſaid nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Mum then, and no more: proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay by Sorcery he got this Isle
From me, he got it. If thy Greatneſſe will
Reuenge it on him, (for I know thou dar'st)
But this Thing dare not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: That's mo’t certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt be Lord of it, and Ile ſerue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: How now ſhall this be compast?
Canst thou bring me to the party?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea, yea my Lord, Ile yeeld him thee asleepe,
Where thou maist knocke a naile into his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou liest, thou canst not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: What a py’de Ninnie's this? Thou ſcuruy patch:
I do beseech thy Greatneſſe giue him blowes,
And take his bottle from him: When that’s gone,
He ſhall drinke nought but brine, for Ile not ſhew him
Where the quicke Freshes are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Trinculo, run into no further danger: Interrupt the Monster one word further, and by this hand, Ile turne my mercie out o' doores, and make a Stockfish of thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what did I? I did nothing:
Ile go farther off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Didst thou not ſay he lyed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou liest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Do I ſo? Take thou that,
As you like this, giue me the lye another time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not giue the lie: Out o'your wittes, and hearing too? A pox o'your bottle, this can Sacke and drinking doo: A murren on your Monster, and the diuell take your fingers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha, ha.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Now forward with your Tale: prethee ſtand further off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Beate him enough: after a little time
Ile beate him too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand farther: Come proceede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, as I told thee, ‘tis a custome with him
I'th afternoone to ſleepe: there thou maist braine him,
Hauing first ſeiz’d his bookes: Or with a logge
Batter his ſkull, or paunch him with a ſtake,
Or cut his wezand with thy knife. Remember
First to poſſeſſe his Bookes; for without them
Hee's but a Sot, as I am; nor hath not
One Spirit to command: they all do hate him
As rootedly as I. Burne but his Bookes,
He ha's braue Vtensils (for ſo he calles them)
Which when he ha's a house, hee'l decke withall.
And that mo’t deeply to consider, is
The beautie of his daughter: he himselfe
Cals her a non-pareill: I neuer ſaw a woman
But onely Sycorax my Dam, and ſhe;
But ſhe as farre ſurpaſſeth Sycorax,
As great'st do's least.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it ſo braue a Laſſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: I Lord, ſhe will become thy bed, I warrant,
And bring thee forth braue brood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Monster, I will kill this man: his daughter and I will be King and Queene, ſaue our Graces: and Trin-culo and thy ſelfe ſhall be Vice-royes: Dost thou like the plot Trinculo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me thy hand, I am ſorry I beate thee:
But while thou liu'st keepe a good tongue in thy head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Within this halfe houre will he be asleepe,
Wilt thou destroy him then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: I on mine honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ariell.
SPEECH.LINE: This will I tell my Master.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou mak'st me merry: I am full of pleasure,
Let vs be iocond. Will you troule the Catch
You taught me but whileare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: At thy request Monster, I will do reason,
Any reason: Come on Trinculo, let vs ſing.
Flout 'em, and cout 'em: and ſkowt 'em, and flout 'em,
Thought is free.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: That's not the tune.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Ariell plaies the tune on a Tabor and Pipe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: What is this ſame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the tune of our Catch, plaid by the pic-ture of No-body.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou beest a man, ſhew thy ſelfe in thy likenes:
If thou beest a diuell, take't as thou list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: O forgiue me my ſinnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: He that dies payes all debts: I defie thee;
Mercy vpon vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou affeard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: No Monster, not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not affeard, the Isle is full of noyses,
Sounds, and ſweet aires, that giue delight and hurt not:
Sometimes a thousand twangling Instruments
Will hum about mine eares; and ſometime voices,
That if I then had wak’d after long ſleepe,
Will make me ſleepe againe, and then in dreaming,
The clouds methought would open, and ſhew riches
Ready to drop vpon me, that when I wak’d
I cri’de to dreame againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: This will proue a braue kingdome to me,
Where I ſhall haue my Musicke for nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cal.
SPEECH.LINE: When Prospero is destroy’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhall be by and by:
I remember the ſtorie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſound is going away,
Lets follow it, and after do our worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ste.
SPEECH.LINE: Leade Monster,
Wee'l follow: I would I could ſee this Taborer,
He layes it on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Trin.
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt come?
Ile follow Stephano.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Anthonio, Gonzallo, Adrian, Francisco, &c

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: By'r lakin, I can goe no further, Sir,
My old bones akes: here's a maze trod indeede
Through fourth-rights, & Meanders: by your patience,
I needes must rest me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: Old Lord, I cannot blame thee,
Who, am my ſelfe attach’d with wearineſſe
To th’ dulling of my ſpirits: Sit downe, and rest:
Euen here I will put off my hope, and keepe it
No longer for my Flatterer: he is droun’d
Whom thus we ſtray to finde, and the Sea mocks
Our frustrate ſearch on land: well, let him goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I am right glad, that he's ſo out of hope:
Doe not for one repulse forgœ the purpose
That you resolu’d t’ effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: The next aduantage will we take throughly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be to night, For now they are oppreſſ’d with trauaile, they Will not, nor cannot vse ſuch vigilance As when they are fresh.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Solemne and ſtrange Musicke: and Prosper on the top (inuisible:) Enter ſeuerall ſtrange ſhapes, bringing in a Banket; and dance about it with gentle actions of ſalutations, and inuiting the King, &c. to eate, they depart

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay to night: no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: What harmony is this? my good friends, harke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Maruellous ſweet Musicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue vs kind keepers, heaue[n]s: what were these?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: A liuing Drolerie: now I will beleeue
That there are Vnicornes: that in Arabia
There is one Tree, the Phœnix throne, one Phœnix
At this houre reigning there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile beleeue both:
And what do's else want credit, come to me
And Ile besworne ‘tis true: Trauellers nere did lye,
Though fooles at home condemne 'em.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: If in Naples
I ſhould report this now, would they beleeue me?
If I ſhould ſay I ſaw ſuch Islands;
(For certes, these are people of the Island)
Who though they are of monstrous ſhape, yet note
Their manners are more gentle, kinde, then of
Our humaine generation you ſhall finde
Many, nay almost any.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Honest Lord,
Thou hast ſaid well: for ſome of you there present;
Are worse then diuels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot too much muse
Such ſhapes, ſuch gesture, and ſuch ſound expreſſing
(Although they want the vse of tongue) a kinde
Of excellent dumbe discourse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Praise in departing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fr.
SPEECH.LINE: They vanish’d ſtrangely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: No matter, ſince
They haue left their Viands behinde; for wee haue ſtomacks.
Wilt please you taste of what is here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alo.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith Sir, you neede not feare: when wee were Boyes
Who would beleeue that there were Mountayneeres,
Dew-lapt, like Buls, whose throats had hanging at 'em
Wallets of flesh? or that there were ſuch men
Whose heads ſtood in their brests? which now we finde
Each putter out of fiue for one, will bring vs
Good warrant of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſtand to, and feede, Although my last, no matter, ſince I feele The best is past: brother: my Lord, the Duke, Stand too, and doe as we.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Thunder and Lightning. Enter Ariell (like a Harpey) claps his wings vpon the Table, and with a quient deuice the Banquet vanishes

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: You are three men of ſinne, whom destiny That hath to instrument this lower world, And what is in't: the neuer ſurfeited Sea, Hath caus’d to belch vp you: and on this Island, Where man doth not inhabit, you 'mongst men, Being mo’t vnfit to liue: I haue made you mad; And euen with ſuch like valour, men hang, and drowne Their proper ſelues: you fooles, I and my fellowes Are ministers of Fate, the Elements Of whom your ſwords are temper’d, may as well Wound the loud windes, or with bemockt-at-Stabs Kill the ſtill closing waters, as diminish One dowle that’s in my plumbe: My fellow ministers Are like-invulnerable: if you could hurt, Your ſwords are now too maſſie for your ſtrengths, And will not be vplifted: But remember (For that’s my busineſſe to you) that you three From Millaine did ſupplant good Prospero, Expos’d vnto the Sea (which hath requit it) Him, and his innocent childe: for which foule deed, The Powres, delaying (not forgetting) haue Incens’d the Seas, and Shores; yea, all the Creatures Against your peace: Thee of thy Sonne, Alonso They haue bereft; and doe pronounce by me Lingring perdition (worse then any death Can be at once) ſhall ſtep, by ſtep attend You, and your wayes, whose wraths to guard you from, Which here, in this mo’t desolate Isle, else fals Vpon your heads, is nothing but hearts-sorrow, And a cleere life ensuing.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: He vanishes in Thunder: then (to ſoft Musicke.) Enter the ſhapes againe, and daunce (with mockes and mowes) and carrying out the Table

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Brauely the figure of this Harpie, hast thou
Perform’d (my Ariell) a grace it had deuouring:
Of my Instruction, hast thou nothing bated
In what thou had'st to ſay: ſo with good life,
And obseruation ſtrange, my meaner ministers
Their ſeuerall kindes haue done: my high charmes work,
And these (mine enemies) are all knit vp
In their distractions: they now are in my powre;
And in these fits, I leaue them, while I visit
Yong Ferdinand (whom they ſuppose is droun’d)
And his, and mine lou’d darling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: I'th name of ſomething holy, Sir, why ſtand you
In this ſtrange ſtare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: O, it is monstrous: monstrous:
Me thought the billowes ſpoke, and told me of it,
The windes did ſing it to me: and the Thunder
(That deepe and dreadfull Organ-Pipe) pronounc’d
The name of Prosper: it did base my Trespaſſe,
Therefore my Sonne i'th Ooze is bedded; and
I'le ſeeke him deeper then ere plummet ſounded,
And with him there lye mudded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Seb.
SPEECH.LINE: But one feend at a time,
Ile fight their Legions ore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be thy Second.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gon.
SPEECH.LINE: All three of them are desperate: their great guilt
(Like poyson giuen to worke a great time after)
Now gins to bite the ſpirits: I doe beseech you
(That are of ſuppler ioynts) follow them ſwiftly,
And hinder them from what this extasie
May now prouoke them to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ad
SPEECH.LINE: Follow, I pray you. Exeunt omnes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: If I haue too austerely punish’d you,
Your compensation makes amends, for I
Haue giuen you here, a third of mine owne life,
Or that for which I liue: who, once againe
